description:
Kozue Ayuhara is a highschool girl and enthusiastic volleyball player. Her dream is to play in the Japanese national volleyball team. During the series she makes it from the school district league up to the Japanese volleyball finals, step by step till the international volleyball championship. But the faster and higher Kozue climbs the career ladder up, the more she gets confronted with the dark side of success: too high expectations, self-conceit and envy are progressing towards serious problems.

(Source: Anime News Network)
synonyms: Mimì e la nazionale di pallavolo

node.description:
Araki developed an interest for drawing at age five. He graduated in Aichi Prefecture. In 1955, at age eighteen, he debuted as a cartoonist in the "Machi" magazine. He then joined Mushi Production as animator in 1964 and later founded Studio Jaccard in 1966. In 1970, he debuted as animation director on [Ashita no Joe](https://anilist.co/anime/2402/), and later worked on the anime adaptations of several of [Gou Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/)'s manga, including [Devilman](https://anilist.co/anime/2252/), [Cutie Honey](https://anilist.co/anime/1661/), and [UFO Robo Grendizer](https://anilist.co/anime/1985/), serving as a character designer on the latter two. In 1971 he founded Studio Z together with his friends in the business.

He frequently worked with animator [Michi Himeno](https://anilist.co/staff/113357/), who he met in 1973. Araki formed Araki Production in 1974 and Himeno was the first member of the studio.

Araki was also an animator on several American productions which outsourced animation work to Japan, including Mighty Orbots (1984, key animation), The Adventures of the American Rabbit (1986) and G.I. Joe: The Movie (1987).

He passed away due to heart failure on December 1, 2011.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小林治_(アニメ演出家%29) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osamu_Kobayashi_(animation_director%29)

Osamu Kobayashi is a Japanese director and animator best known for [Creamy Mami](https://anilist.co/anime/2044/). In 1963, he entered Toei Animation at the same time as [Tsutomu Shibayama](https://anilist.co/staff/119556/) and [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/). He was a chief animator working with Shibayama after having transferred to a A Production. In 1978, he established [Ajia-do](https://anilist.co/studio/30/) together with Shibayama.

_Note: Not to be confused with the 1964 born director, [Osamu Kobayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100406/)._

Perhaps most well known for his work as a character designer on the anime television series [Armored Trooper Votoms](https://anilist.co/anime/2582/). He was also one of the founding members of [Oh! Production](https://anilist.co/studio/234/), together with [Kouichi Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/191548/), [Kazuo Komatsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/129558/), and Koushin Yonekawa.

In 1966, Shioyama joined Hatena Pro under the direction of [Bonjin Nagaki](https://anilist.co/staff/117141/). Shioyama later became a freelancer, doing work for [Tatsunoko Pro](https://anilist.co/studio/103/) and working on many projects for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) as an animation director. Shioyama's first project as a character designer was for [Invincible Steel Man Daitarn 3](https://anilist.co/anime/3305/), which anime director [Ryousuke Takahashi](https://anilist.co/staff/100957/) praised. He then worked on such shows as [Fang of the Sun Dougram](https://anilist.co/anime/2257/), [Panzer World Galient](https://anilist.co/anime/5153/), and [Ronin Warriors](https://anilist.co/anime/1264/) as both character designer and animation director. His and Takahashi's designs epitomized Sunrise's work in the '80s.

On April 13, 2017, a fire occurred at Shioyama's apartment in Misato, sadly killing both him and his wife.

He's a screenwriter who mainly deals with anime works.  During his training, he also studied under Kohan Kawauchi. In that connection, he also participates in anime and special effects works based on Kawauchi. In the 1980s, he was active in working on multiple works at the same time. There is a wide range of genres, from gag lines to serious ones. In recent years, he has also worked on original works such as graphic novels for men. Since the 2000s, he has been working on period drama novels.

He graduated from Hôsei University.
He was a music composer for anime, drama and jidaigeki from Tokyo, Japan. He passed away from renal failure.

Takamura Mukuo was a famous art director from Sasebo, Nagasaki, Japan. He was a graduate of Musashino Art University, where he majored in Western Painting. After graduating in 1963, Mukuo joined Tokyo Movie Studio and started his career as a background artist for animation. In 1966, he established his own studio, Mukuo Group and Mukuo Studio in 1968, which was incorporated three years later in 1971.

Some of his best known works include the feature film [Cello Hiki no Gauche](https://anilist.co/anime/1049/) and [Haha o Tazunete Sanzenri](https://anilist.co/anime/1663/), part of the WMT series, both directed by [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/). For the latter he visited actual places in Italy and Argentina together with Takahata and Miyazaki, to ensure an authentic feel to the series.

He was also known for his contribution to science-fiction anime franchises [Uchuu Senkan Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/), [Uchuu Kaizoku Captain Harlock](https://anilist.co/anime/1000/) and [Ginga Tetsudou 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1491/).

He was awarded the first grand-prix of the first anime popularity contest in the category of art, which was organised by the publisher Tokuma-Shoten. The contest was won by Mukuo five times in a row, until it was cancelled, making him the only winner in the art category.

Mukuo had greatly contributed to the rapid development of the animation in Japan during the 1970s and 80s.

He passed away from cancer on June 9, 1992 at the age of 54. At that time he was working on the [Bishoujo Senshi Sailor Moon](https://anilist.co/anime/530/) series. [Tadao Kubota](https://anilist.co/staff/154564/) took over his place but Mukuo was still credited as art designer of the Sailor Moon series subsequently for all later works.

Tadao Kubota, who was a manager at the Mukuo Studio, took also over Mukuo's duties as representative director of the studio.

In April 2004 a book that collected all of his best works was released posthumously. Titled Takamura Mukuo: The Art of Animation and supervised by Keiko Mukuo and Tadao Kubota, it does include much of Mukuo's background art, image boards, and plans to masterpieces like Ginga Tetsudou 999, Haha o Tazunete Sanzenri, [Neo Tokyo](https://anilist.co/anime/1951/), Cello Hiki no Gauche, Sailor Moon and [Kamui no Ken](https://anilist.co/anime/496/).

[Website](https://www.maocloud.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/MaoCloud) |  [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/maomaowsan/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/MaoCloud)

Multi-talented freelance artist who specialized in depicting nature, such as clouds and waves.

After graduating from high school, he joined [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/), and worked under [Keiichirou Kimura](https://anilist.co/staff/168326/). Later joined Madhouse and was one of the studio's leading animators during its early days together with [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/) and [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/).
Keishi Yamazaki is a producer and screenwriter.

Occasionally credited alongside his company Inoue Henshuu-shitsu (井上編集室)/Inoue Editing Room

_Note: Not to be confused with the [animator](https://anilist.co/staff/197572/)._

After finishing school, Yoshida went to Tokyo, where he joined Toei in 1959. 10 years later - 1969 - he left Toei to work at Shin'ei Doga and Tokyo Movie Shinsha where he worked as a director for single episodes for the first time.

Founded [Oh! Production](https://anilist.co/studio/234/) together with [Norio Shioyama](https://anilist.co/staff/106503/), [Kazuo Komatsubara](https://anilist.co/staff/129558/) and [Koushin Yonekawa](https://anilist.co/staff/206630/) in 1970. He also acted as a producer on a handful of the titles the studio produced, and served as its representative director from its founding up until his unfortunate passing from a subarachnoid hemorrhage in 2006.

After graduating from high school, Dezaki took a position at Toshiba while studying in the department of literature at Hosei University. While doing both of these, he continued to work on his dream job of working on movie production. He acted as the coach for the nine-member volleyball team at Toshiba. Dezaki also began pulling together an anime production team.

Dezaki resigned after working for seven years at Toshiba, leaving Hosei University in the middle of a term as well. He began working for [Gisaburou Sugii's](https://anilist.co/staff/103537) company Art Fresh, working alongside his younger brother [Osamu](https://anilist.co/staff/100393). His first works included writing the script for [Attack No.1](https://anilist.co/anime/1550) and storyboarding [Kyojin no Hoshi](https://anilist.co/anime/5834).

In 1969, Dezaki became a freelancer, doing scripting, production and direction work for [Tokyo Movie Shinsha](https://anilist.co/studio/65), [Tatsunoko Production](https://anilist.co/studio/103), and [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14). In 1977, he founded [Magic Bus](https://anilist.co/studio/207) and produced and animated [Shin Kyojin no Hoshi](https://anilist.co/anime/15875).

He is the older brother of [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393), and the husband of [Setsuko Shibuichi](https://anilist.co/staff/101935/).
He was a screenwriter for anime and tokusatsu shows. He had written scripts for the Anime series "Kinniku Man" and its subsequent movies.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/mtsujiji) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/辻真先) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masaki_Tsuji)

Tsuji was most active in the business from the '60s through the '80s, and worked as a screenwriter on many popular anime television series for [Mushi Production](https://anilist.co/studio/68/), [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/), and [Tokyo Movie Shinsha](https://anilist.co/studio/65/). He is well known for his association with the animated adaptations of the works of [Osamu Tezuka](https://anilist.co/staff/96938/) and [Go Nagai](https://anilist.co/staff/97992/). In April 2007, Tsuji headed Japan's first international anime research lab as part of Digital Hollywood University. In 2007, he was given a lifetime achievement award at the 11th Japan Media Arts Festival. In 2008, he won a Special Award in the 13th Animation Kobe for his writing work.

(Source: Wikipedia)
Youzou Kataoka is a sound effects editor.
